headline: Indian Fish Curry
description: This Indian fish curry features mustard-marinated fish baked with tomatoes in a spicy cashew purée. The recipe was inspired by a Bengali fish recipe.

video.description: Tasty white fish fillets are baked in a spicy curry sauce.
video.name: Indian Fish Curry

name: Indian Fish Curry
recipeIngredient: 1 (1 inch) piece fresh ginger root, peeled and chopped
2 teaspoons cayenne pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Mix 2 tablespoons oil, mustard, black pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon salt together in a shallow glass bowl. Add fish and turn to coat. Cover and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
While the fish is marinating, combine onion, garlic, ginger, and cashews in a blender or food processor; pulse until mixture forms a paste.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Heat remaining 1 tablespoon oil in a skillet over medium-low heat. Add cashew paste; cook and stir until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Add cayenne pepper, remaining 1 teaspoon salt, cumin, coriander, sugar, and turmeric; cook and stir for 5 minutes. Stir in tomato and broth.
Remove fish from marinade and shake off excess; discard remaining marinade. Arrange fish in a baking dish and pour sauce over top.
Bake, covered, in the preheated oven until fish flakes easily with a fork, about 30 minutes. Garnish with cilantro.

review.reviewBody: This was amazing!! Besides using half the cayenne (which was just right for me), I followed the recipe as written. I used cod because it was on sale and looked good and canned petite diced tomatoes. I made the sauce the night before, which made it pretty quick and easy to get the dish in the oven when I got home from work. My fish took a little longer to cook, probably because the fillets were pretty thick. I took it out when the fish got to 130 degrees, and it was perfectly done. I can't wait to make this again!
We made it with cod and it was delicious!

I followed the recipe exactly and found it to be extremely spicy. We love hot & spicy but this was so hot it was not enjoyable. Next time I would reduce the spice to a bit less than half of what it calls for.
Turned out really good but doubled the curry to cover the Swai filets I used. Cayenne pepper was a bit much but still a great dish.
Loved it. I did find it pretty salty so next time I will back off a bit on the salt. Also we cut the cayenne petter by about 2/3. We will definitely be making this again!
No curry powder. Excellent!

My first time making curry and it was fantastic! I used Cod and Mahi Mahi because that's what I had in the freezer. The taste of the sauce was absolutely amazing - and very spicy!!! I even like a little spice but this was hot!
Loved it! I left out the sugar, and we didn't miss it.
Absolutely delicious!
I made it exactly as directed. I thought the tumeric was overpowering and it was a bit spicy. Next time I will try with less turmeric and will double the tomatoes
Made it following the recipe and loved it. Even better as leftovers.

Love this recipe! However, it was way too spicy for us as written. I would recommend starting with 1/4 to 1 teaspoon of cayenne - you can always add more but can’t take it away! This was the first Indian recipe I made for my Bengali boyfriend (now husband) and years later I still make it all the time. If I use canned tomato’s and frozen fish fillets, I usually have the ingredients on hand. I’ve used all kinds of fish (including salmon) and all worked great.
First time making curry. This recipie was easy and fantastic. I only used half a tea spoon of cayenne pepper and it was hot enough for me. Can't imagine using the two teas spoons

Incredible flavour! I’m so glad I came across this dish. A new way to cook pickerel or walleye as it’s also known as. I didn’t have cashews so I used almonds. Added a bit of peanut butter as someone suggested. Cut back the cayenne to one tsp. I can’t wait to make this again.
Love this recipe have done this many times on our own and with friends. It is spot on..I used halibut as it lends it self to take on the wonderful flavours. The aroma in house is superb.
So hot I found it inedible as written.

My brother even liked it! 
I thought it was fabulous and not too hard to make. I didn’t have a food processor or a blender, so I used a mortar and pestle. Yes it took a bit missing time but it came out perfect!

It's good, but it is spicy and I used half of the black pepper called for (1 tsp is a lot anytime!!) and half the cayenne pepper. Had I followed the recipe I would not have been able to eat it because, although I live in Kenya and love Indian food, I'm a bit of a wimp. :)

This definitely served its purpose of giving me something to do with fish other than bread/fry. The flavor was good, but I used about the amount of cayenne pepper recommended and it was nearly too hot for me and my husband to eat. I would probably make it again, but with about half the amount of cayenne.

The recipe was very easy to fellow and to make . I did not change any ingredients in the Indian Fish Curry. Everything came out perfectly and delicious . Cooking time was about the same as Mantu stated. My family enjoyed the Indian fish curry very much. I will definitely cook this again. Thanks Mantu! Edna Gibbs
Followed recipe as-is. Everyone enjoyed it and will make again.
I loved it, definitely make it again. I love curry and this is my favorite recipe so far.
Cut the cayenne in half and made exactly as stated with fresh ingredients bought the same day. The taste of the sauce was absolutely terrible. We love fish and couldn't finish it. What a waste.
This dish is AMAZING! My boo applauded me and we devoured this! So much flavor. I went a little over the 2tsps of Cayenne and didn’t have coriander, so I added dried cilantro.
Made it for my wife and she thought it was better than the restaurant. Loved it! Added a little extra cayenne to give it s really good kick.

Didn't really have fillets, but had a couple of nice slabs of halibut that I cut into bite-sized pieces. Upped the tomatoes and broth (chicken as it were) & served over Tex-mati rice. Nice heat that almost dominated the other flavors, but all in all an excellent dish. Got nice compliments from the crowd (wife) & had enough for a second meal later in the week. Definite do-again experimenting with spices & herbs.

Way too spicy!! I’m a southern Cajun girl, & I love spicy things. When I eat my boiled crawfish, I want my nose to be running or it’s not spicy enough. But this? This takes it to a whole new level. It wasn’t even pleasant. Way too much “fire”. My husband & I scraped all the paste off of our fish.
Absolutely delicious! I improvised and added shrimp to the recipe and made basmati rice with saffron... this dish was out of this world !!!

This was excellent. I only made very minor adaptations. Instead of the 2 tsp cayenne pepper, I used 1 tsp Madiera Curry powder and 1/2 tsp. ancho chili pepper. I also added 1/2 cup of frozen peas to the sauce right before putting it in the oven. It was fantastic.
I’ve made this several times now, always to rave reviews. I meter out the cayenne based on my guests preference but enjoy the spice myself. I prefer it with rockfish

The smells from the kitchen were incredible and the dish was quite flavorful. I discovered I didn't have any cayenne pepper so substituted red chili pepper flakes that I didn't measure before adding. I will definitely make this again.
It was tasty, but a lot of chopping etc. I did reduce the cayenne pepper. I would have liked a firmer white fish as my flou der was lost.

This recipe is great!! I'm American and my husband is Indian so I'm trying to learn to cook traditional foods for him. He loved this recipe so much that it's become a regular at our house. He said fish curry is hard to get right and was super impressed that I got it so spot on, so thank you for sharing!! The fish is pretty spicy but that's how it's supposed to be, and I usually double the sauce because its so delicious!
Really tasty! Used 1/2 tsp of cayenne.... just the right amount of heat for me. Will definitely be making again!

I really liked this. I left out the cashews because I don’t care for them but other than that I followed the recipe. It was pretty easy to make and had a really nice flavor. Paired with asparagus and broccoli and it was a flavorful and healthy way to get some fish in. I’ll make it again.
My family needs less cayenne pepper, but was great as it was.

I used just one tsp. of cayenne which was hot enough for us, but the rest of the recipe was unchanged. I served this over rice and wilted spinach as suggested by another reviewer. This was a big hit with my husband and it's a healthy meal, so I will definitely be making it again.

Love this recipe! I didn’t make any changes except using ginger paste instead of fresh ginger. I used orange roughy fillets and shrimp, cutting the fillets in smaller pieces before marinating. Served over basmati rice - definitely a keeper!
I will make this again. It was very flavorful. Made as written however used 1 tsp of cayenne and Rotel cilantro tomatoes and it had a good spice heat. Thank you for this.
So so good! Followed the recipe exactly... EXCEPT for the cayenne pepper part due to sensitive taste buds in the family. I halved the amount only adding 1 tsp.
I love this recipe. The only change that I will make the next time I make this dish is less sugar

Outstanding! This is absolutely delicious!

Hubby loved it; said it was the most authentic Indian dish I've ever made. I don't like fish but keep trying to make myself eat it. This recipe did the trick.

This will definitely be my go to sauce/recipe from now on!

I made this for dinner tonight. I didn't use as much cayenne as the recipe called for but it was spiced very well and we had no problem eating it all. We will definitely have this again. I'm sure guests will love it as well.
I made w/ chicken boullion since I didn't have vegetable broth and I thought it was on the salty side; I might make it again w/ vegetable broth instead and see how it is.
I made this last week and I loved it. I guess depending on your taste buds, I think this was spicy enough for me. Thank you
I made this last week and I loved it. I guess depending on your taste buds, I think this was spicy enough for me. Thank you
I only used 1 tsp of cayenne and it was pretty hot, but sooooo good. I will definitely be making his again

I have made this twice. The first time I made it with cod and followed the recipe to the letter. There was way too much cayenne pepper for my taste, but my husband liked it. I also wasn't crazy about the cod. The second time I made it with tilapia and cut the cayenne down to 1/2 tsp. It still had enough kick for him, but it wasn't too much for me. I put it over rice that I made with some of the leftover vegatable broth from the recipe instead of water. I also sprinkled in some cumin, turmeric, coriander, salt, pepper, and garam masala. It went well with the fish. It was a great meal and I'll definitely make it again.

My husband can be pretty critical, but he loved this dish! (He said serving it with rice is a must.) 
 The only changes I made were less cayenne (per others' suggestions), fish stock instead of vegetable stock, and crunchy peanut butter in place of cashews (1.5 tablespoons--I had no cashews on hand). Still a bit spicy hot, but perfect to me, as I love spicy hot foods! Better than the Indian restaurants I have tried!
delicious

Wow! Possibly the best recipe on Allrecipes. Amazing - I use all of these ingredients all the time, but never tasted anything like this out of my kitchen. Wonderful flavor. I used olive oil because I don't like canola oil and 1 t cayenne, and one large filet of wild salmon, skin on bottom. Marinated in the baking dish I used and did not discard the marinate, just dumped the curry sauce on top of the fish before baking. Dressed it with thin slices of mango around the edges. What a delight.

I didn't make any changes when I made it. My husband and I must be woosier than we thought! We found it VERY hot and spicy, and weren't ready for it. The next night we had sour cream on hand and it was delicious! The fish was cooked perfectly in the time posted.
This was VERY spicy and EXTREMELY good! I used thick pieces of Cod. My coriander was whole so i skipped it & had to use coconut milk for the broth because I didn't have that either .

We just made this for the first time, and it was fabulous! I used some sole filets and followed recipe almost exactly except for the ginger root which I did not have on hand. I was a little concerned that the garlic might be overpowering, and a little surprised to be adding sugar, but the flavors all blended perfectly. Very flavorful. This recipe will definitely be added to our rotation of fish dishes, thanks!!
Made as stated but did half the cayenne. Delicious dish.

This is a great recipe. However the instruction page is wrong. After the marinade contents, other contents are listed which are for the main cooking instructions. The marinade instruction finishes when you add the fish to the marinade.
This was unbelievable! I don't like fish but this made it tasty, even for my fish lovers. Will definitely make again!

Followed the recipe but cut the salt in half and prepared the night before so after covering the cod fillets with the paste I covered the casserole with foil and put it in the fridge. Half an hour in the oven and served along with mashed sweet potatoes, jasmine rice, a little shredded coconut, some raisins and some homemade rhubarb chutney. My daughter had trouble with the heat but didn't leave anything on her plate!

Followed the recipe but cut the salt in half and prepared the night before so after covering the cod fillets with the paste I covered the casserole with foil and put it in the fridge. Half an hour in the oven and served along with mashed sweet potatoes, jasmine rice, a little shredded coconut, some raisins and some homemade rhubarb chutney. My daughter had trouble with the heat but didn't leave anything on her plate!

This was so good! It is a good way to make fish that is unique and delicious. The balance of spices and the richness of the oil are the perfect complement to the blandness of fish. I used flounder and served it over basmati rice.
A little too spicy. I'd cut back on some of the spices next time, but otherwise very tasty.
liked it
I love this recipe, especially that it uses whole spices rather than "a teaspoon of curry powder" making it much more authentic and richly flavored.

A favourite in our house! The teens request it often. I use only 3/4 tsp cayenne (personal preference) increase tomato to 1 cup and add 1/2 can coconut milk for creaminess and just because the sauce is so delicious we like to have extra to spoon over rice. We use about 6 Basa fillets - super tender! Another great thing about this dish (compared to many fish dishes) - it keeps in the oven covered at 200 degrees without drying as we discovered one night when dinner was ready but family was an hour late getting home. This is a restaurant-quality recipe, great with naan and a simple crunchy salad with an oil & vinegar dressing. Thanks for the recipe :)
fantastic also served with couscous!!!

Made this last night according to recipe (added crushed cardamom seeds). Used Orange Roughy and baked for 25 minutes. Taste was excellent - on the very spicy side! Only issue was trying to blend (pulse) spices and onions. into paste. After 15 minutes of toing and froing, I gave up on it ever becoming a paste, but it turned out OK.

Made it with 1/2 tsp cayenne and lots of cilantro. Yum.
Next time will use only 1/4 tsp of cayenne, omit the sugar and soak the cashews.

Very tasty. Not very spicy as recipe calls, so if you like a little "kick" add some hot sauce. We like "Satan's Blood" which is a chili extract, not a hot sauce. I do have to ask though, why is this called "curry" when there is no curry in it?

This dish was terrific! So tasty! We're big curry fans and this was was very authentic. I made it for 2 people and made it a low fat dish by omitting all oil. I used a 1 lb swordfish steak cut into 1 inch chunks. To marinate, I placed the chunks in a small baking dish and covered with 5 forkfuls of minced garlic from a jar and about 5 Tblsp of Dijon mustard. For the curry I used minced ginger from a jar for convenience. 1 tsp of cayenne was plenty spicy for us. In my opinion I could have left the cashew halves out and not known the difference. I cooked the sauce without oil, it wasn't necessary, and used Splenda instead of sugar. Two diced Roma tomatoes worked for me, and I put the sauce right on top of the marinade before baking. I left off the cilantro garnish because I don't care for it. Served it with steamed cauliflower and a sliced banana, and for anyone on Weight Watchers the entire dinner came out to 7 SmartPoints per serving. Husband liked this a lot and so did I; I will definitely make this again!

I also usually order at least medium spicy, but my cayenne is insane (I've noticed this in other recipes) so unfortunately the sauce on this was almost inedibly hot. And that's after I cut it down to 1/2 t! But the recipe was delicious, especially with some greek yogurt on the side, and we really liked the overall flavor it imparted to the fish. I served with brown basmati and a curry-slathered roasted cauliflower, which was a really nice combo.

This fish curry was so super delicious! I used a fish curry powder mix instead of turmeric, coriander and cumin powder and added more garlic to the paste. I give this 5 stars and would give more if that was possible and it will be saved in my favorites. Thanks for sharing this incredible recipe! :)

I followed the recipe exactly and while it was good, it was way too hot. Next time I will cut back to 1 tsp of cayenne. Otherwise a good way to liven up meal with fish. I served it with basmati rice and a Thai cucumber salad.
I followed the recipe instructions. I enjoyed using the oven to cook Indian food. This is going to be a regular recipe that I would like to cook.
Delicious and spicy. Worth the effort.

When I took my first bite I was not very impressed. My husband said it was "interesting". Both of us ended up liking it by the time we were finished our dinner. I used 1 tsp cayenne and found that it was plenty spicy. I used cod as that was what I had. My cod was previously frozen and was water logged when I thawed it. I blotted it really well with paper towels so that it would not cook up watery. The fish texture was good after cooking. I didn't love the texture of the sauce or the visual appearance of it. Next time I will skip the food processor and finely dice everything.. I will also decrease the amount of salt. With a bit of tweaking, this will be great for our personal preferences. Thanks for the recipe!
I cut out a little of the cayenne for my kids. Other than that, I made it according to the recipe. It came out amazing. Will definitely favorite this and make it again soon.

I am just starting to cook Indian food as i love spices like cumin,turmeric,coriander. I made this with fresh Georgian Bay whitefish. Followed the recipe ingredients ,only cut back on the cayenne pepper and added some red pepper flakes. Also more cashews ,more vegetable broth and a heaping tbs of tomato paste as my tomatoes were frozen and pretty tasteless. Love the sauce ..yummy...make more sauce .it is so tasty. Will definitely make this again.

I made this for the first time this weekend for four dinner guests and my husband. I used wild caught cod as well as wild caught shrimp. It was amazing. My guests loved it as well as my husband. The flavors were awesome even with forgetting to add the cilantro.. I served it with Basmati rice, cauliflower / string bean medley and Naan which my guests were using to dip into that delicious sauce. Definitely would make again!!!!
Excellent dish. Quite spicy. Quick to put together. Yum

Excellent. Used only 1/4 tsp cayenne and 1/2 jalapeno in onion paste mixture. Didn't have turmeric so added a very mild curry powder and used 1 tsp hot mango chutney instead of sugar. Used twice the amount of tomatoes. Used fresh red snapper. Served over cumin seed basmati rice. Would definitely serve to company.
The dish was great everyone loved it at my house I used some tomato ketchup to add a sweet flavor to it

Ugh, mine didn't come out well at all.:P The sweetness of the sugar was overpowering (and I used RAW cane sugar, which isn't as sweet as refined white sugar!), so I would suggest cutting the sugar that the recipes calls for way down. In all fairness, I did replace the dry ingredients with my go-to curry masala, but that should not have affected how sweet this curry was! I did use frozen fish (as the option was noted in this recipe), but it turned out chewy and tough, not like the tender flakes of fresh cod at all. In terms of taste, I would have rated this recipe one star, but given that I didn't follow this recipe completely (I used my own curry masala instead), I compensated with the extra star.
Loved it. Will make again.
Used Grenadier Fillets for this recipe and only used 1 tsp of Cayenne pepper which the kids ate but found a bit spicy so maybe next time I will cut back to 3/4. Perfect recipe and will make again.

This was a very interesting dish. I think it would be better with chicken, but it definitely changed things up for our normal white fish! I served this over brown rice with steamed veggies, it was very filling. It was spicier than expected, but yummy!

I’ve made this at least a half dozen times, and it is ALWAYS incredibly delicious! It is literally one of the best things I make. It is ALWAYS good, and ALWAYS flavorful! As others have said, I only use a fraction of the cayenne, though. DELISH!!!
The technique was cool, but it was way too salty. The spice mix doesn't need anywhere near that much salt.
I made mine with tilapia and the only change I made was a used 1.5 tsp of cayenne pepper. It was wonderfully moist and flavorful!

Heaven. The best recipe I've ever found online. Family raved about it. Plus, everyone who ate it had extremely interesting, vivid dreams that night. Something about the combination of ingredients causes amazing dreams.

My husband is the only person who eats fish curries in our home. He loved it! I think I followed the recipe completely, except that I baked it at 400 F and used frozen tomatoes that I had saved from my garden produce.
Wow! Nothing less! Wow!
I found it had a slightly bitter taste. Everyone else said they enjoyed it. I won't bother making this again.

Restaurant Quality right here!!

I'm a vegetarian, so I do not eat fish but my husband still does. This recipe was amazing. The curry flavor was very good. I adjusted the recipe for 3 servings and followed the recipe that way. I followed all directions as stated except I had no fresh tomatoes. For that, I used 1.5 TBS of tomato sauce. I also used about a half palm size of unsalted cashew pieces since I didn't have any whole cashews. ETA: when we go to the Indian restaurants, we usually ask for a level 4/mild. I made this curry using only 1/4 tsp and it was a good amount. He said he'd rate it level 1 spiciness from an Indian restaurant.

I used 3 wild caught flounder filets for this dish. In the future, I will definitely make more of the sauce! It's extremely flavorful. I found myself constantly tasting it.
didn't care for this. it was really bitter. is that normal? I'm new to Indian cuisine.
Didn't care for it at all.

Huge hit at my house! I did make a few changes...used mahi mahi and shrimp,1 teaspoon of cayenne(my daughter won't eat to hot) and used 2 tablespoons of creamy peanut butter (no cashews in the house). I did put all the curry sauce ingredients into the blend to purée and cooked the curry sauce for a good solid hour to have all the flavor blend. To cook the fish I put it into a sauté pan than added the curry sauce cooked a good 10 mins...served over spinach and rice with mango chutney. My daughter wanted to know when I would make it again....that means it's a hit!

I used the whole 2 tsp of red pepper. Husband loved it. I thought it was funny to have the name curry in it and there's no actual curry in it! We used our favorite fish: snakehead. It's a very mild fish. I think it's the best fish out there.
A new meatless Monday family favorite!
Amazing! Used Chilean sea bass so it was very hearty. Next time I would add more cashews and a pinch more sugar but the recipe as it was fab! And topped it over spiraled zucchini instead of rice
